question: Which of the following laboratory tests is useful for the management of patients infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)?

A 28-year-old male comes to the emergency room with complaints of rising fever for the past 4 days, which was initially low grade and has become high grade. He also complains of generalized weakness and abdominal pain. On general examinations, the vitals are; blood pressure: 100/60 mm Hg, pulse: 64 beats per minute, temperature: 103 °F, respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute. The systemic examination is unremarkable. What is the patient most likely suffering from?

An afebrile patient comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of passing large number of stools frequently. On microscopic examination of the stool, no red blood cells and white blood cells are found. Which of the following conditions best relate to the patient's complaint?
A urea breath test is performed on a patient of which of the following conditions?
When taking the history of diarrhea in children, what is the most important combination of signs or symptoms that is needed to be asked?
The rapid urease test is a diagnostic test for which disease?
Which of the following organisms is the vector for the dengue virus?
What is the reason for relapsing fever in cases of malaria by Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infection?
What is the first-line medication for the treatment of enteric fever?
Cheese-like discharge is a characteristic of which of the following diseases?
Which of the below-enlisted opportunistic infections is typically seen in HIV infection with a CD4 count of fewer than 100 cells/mm3?
HIV-infected patients with a CD4 count below 500 cells/mm3 are predisposed to which of the following opportunistic pathogens?

An 18-year-old boy, who has migrated from Quetta to Karachi, presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, lethargy, and reduced appetite since the past week. History suggests that he is working at a tandoor (roti) shop for the last 3 months and lives in an unhygienic environment. He drinks tap water. On examination, a faint, salmon-colored, maculopapular rash is noticed on his trunk. Apart from a complete blood count (CBC), what is the next most appropriate test to diagnose his illness?

A 6-year-old child is brought by her mother with the complaint of severe agitation and disturbed sleep at night for the past week. On inquiry, the child admits she has severe perianal itching at night. What is the most likely cause?
What is the screening test of choice for HIV in neonates?
What is the incubation period of Mycobacterium leprae?

A 30-year-old man sustained a bat bite to his arm during a camping trip. He presents to a medical facility 12 hours later and is clinically asymptomatic. What postexposure prophylaxis should be given to this patient?
Which of the following drugs is given with beta-lactam antibiotics for synergistic effect?

A 10-year-old child is brought to the pediatric emergency room with severe watery diarrhea for the past 2 days. On inquiry, the mother exclaims her child has been passing large volumes of rice-water colored stools, 10-12 episodes per day. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young female is brought to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She had a meal consisting of rice and curry at a local restaurant 3 hours prior to the onset of her symptoms. What is the likely etiologic agent?
What is the treatment for tertiary syphilis?

answers.option: Single dose of intramuscular penicillin G

question: A 41-year-old man, with a history of HIV/AIDS, presents to the outpatient clinic with worsening dyspnea and cough for the last 5 days. The cough is non-productive and associated with a low-grade fever. A CD4+ count is ordered and is found to be 160 cells/mm3. Bronchoalveolar lavage, treated with methenamine silver staining, shows disc-shaped yeast cells. Which of the following organisms is most likely linked to this man's condition?

A 21-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a mild fever and increased urinary frequency. She complains of urinary hesitancy and also pain while urinating. She also reports pain in the pubic area after voiding. There is no history of chills, rigors, or nausea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the first line of treatment in a patient with tetanus?

A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium. A complete blood count shows eosinophilia and a chest X-ray shows calcification below the right diaphragm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old male, farmer by profession presents to the outpatient clinic with vague right-sided abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Laboratory and radiological workups reveal hydatid cyst disease of the liver. This is his second recurrence in 2 years. What is the treatment for this patient?
Relapses are associated with which species of Plasmodium?

A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless ulcer on the shaft of the penis. He has no symptoms otherwise. Clinical examination reveals rubbery enlargement of bilateral inguinal lymph nodes. What is the most likely causative agent?
Which of the following organs is not affected in mumps?
What is the diagnostic investigation of choice for hydatid cyst disease?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with a high-grade fever, irritability, and headache for the past 2 days. During inpatient evaluation, he develops a tonic-clonic fit that lasts for 1 minute. CSF examination reveals gram-negative diplococci with pleocytosis and high protein levels. What is the most likely causative agent?
Which of the following clinical features is typically the first sign of tetanus?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with uncontrolled muscle spasms and lockjaw. A provisional diagnosis of tetanus is made and appropriate therapy is started. What is the antibiotic therapy for this infection?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with fever and pain in his right cheek for the past 1 week. On clinical examination, unilateral facial swelling is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male, farmer by profession is being operated on for an 8 x 10 cm cyst visualized on an ultrasound abdomen. The patient presented with vague upper right-sided abdominal pain for the past 6 months. Surgical removal of the cyst reveals multiple daughter cysts. What is the causative agent?
What is the most common type of tetanus?
What is the treatment of choice for Entamoeba histolytica infection?
What is the best initial test for HIV infection?
A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a swollen jaw and pain upon chewing for 3 days. The swelling is bilateral and associated with mild fever. What is the diagnosis?
Which of the following bacteria is known to be a usual cause of bloody diarrhea?

The presumptive diagnosis of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is sometimes made with the help of antibodies found in the patient's serum using enzyme-linked immunoassay (ELISA). Which test is confirmatory for HIV infection?
Which can help in the diagnosis of factitious fever?

A 27-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of fever for the past 2 days. Temperature is 102°F upon examination, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and heart rate is 64 beats per minute. He is admitted to the ward and a few hours later his fever is 104°F and then falls to 101°F. What is the most likely diagnosis in this man?
What is the appropriate treatment for typhoid fever in adults?

A 24-year-old farmer comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of difficulty in opening his mouth. He also has a small wound in the heel of his right foot. On examination, generalized body stiffness is found. He is rushed to the emergency room for further evaluation of suspected tetanus. Which of the following is an important step in the management of tetanus?
A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit due to sepsis. He is being mechanically ventilated. What should be the central venous pressure (CVP)?
Which history is not significant to ask from a patient who presents with a suspected case of sexually transmitted infection?

answers.option: Do you masturbate on regular basis?
When did you last have sex?
In your life, have your sexual partners been male, female or both?
Do you have a regular sexual partner at present?

question: Due to the risk of which of the following is it mandatory for the people traveling to Africa to get vaccinated?

A 15-year-old boy comes into the emergency department. He has had a history of fever for the last 2 weeks, initially, low-grade 100 F, followed by high-grade with severe abdominal pain. His blood culture is done as an outpatient is positive for Salmonella typhi with sensitivity to azithromycin and imipenem-cilastatin. An X-ray of the abdomen, erect and supine, shows gas under the right diaphragm. What is the most common site of gut perforation in enteric fever?

A 20-year-old female presents with a history of fever for five days. She also complains of abdominal pain and constipation. On examination, the temperature is 101 F, the pulse is 68 beats per minute and the rest is unremarkable. The doctor suspects enteric fever. Which of the following is true regarding the investigation?

answers.option: Urine culture is positive in first week
Stool culture is positive in the first week
Widal test is the most sensitive
The sensitivity of typhidot is nearly 100%
Blood culture is the most useful diagnostic test at this stage

question: A 25-year-old woman from the Lyari district comes to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia, flatulence, and abdominal cramps with diarrhea. She tells that she has had the same complaints two weeks before as well. Complete blood count shows marked leukocytosis while the stool examination shows pear-shaped trophozoites. What would the most probable diagnosis be?
A child is brought to the clinic for medical consultation with complaints of painful swelling of the parotid gland, fever and difficulty in swallowing. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
The late stage of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The decline in the number of which of the following cells manifests this stage?
A 35-year-old male consults to physician after being bitten by a stranded dog within 24 hours. What post-exposure prophylaxis regime will the doctor offer him after local wound care or cleaning?

answers.option: 20 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 3 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
10 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
20 IU/kg human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) plus 5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV)
5 doses of 1 ml human diploid cell vaccine (HDCV); intramuscular (I/M)

question: A young male develops a high-grade fever intermittent in nature and occurring every 48 hours. Later on, his laboratory report reveals that he has vivax malaria. Which subtype fever does he have?
Fever, a biological effect of endotoxin, occurs due to the release of which of the following endogenous pyrogens?
In a stool sample of a 10-year-old Muslim child admitted for abdominal pain, flat ribbon-like segments with scolices are seen. What would the most probable diagnosis be?
Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease causing multiple deformities of extremities. Which of the following statements is correct regarding its incubation period?

answers.option: The incubation period averages few months
The incubation period averages few days
The incubation period averages several years
The incubation period averages few weeks
The incubation period averages several hours

question: Measles is primarily a childhood disease characterized by fever, runny nose, cough, and maculopapular rash. What is its diagnosis usually done by?
Which of the following is the most sensitive test for diagnosis of liver hydatid cyst?
If a multi-bacillary leprosy patient, treated with standard fixed-duration multi-drug therapy, starts having relapses, what among the following regimen should be started?
In which stage or phase of human acquired immunodeficiency (HIV) virus infection is the term 'acquired immunodeficiency syndrome' (AIDS) used to denote the disease?

answers.option: Last stage of human acquired immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
Incubation period of human acquired immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
Convalescent phase of human acquired immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
Initial phase of human acquired immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection
Infective period of human acquired immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection

question: A 22-year-old student comes with a positive test for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). He is taking intravenous drugs for the past year. His physical examination is unremarkable. His laboratory tests and investigations are all fine, and the CD4+ lymphocyte count is within the normal range at 750. What would the best course of action be to start antiretroviral therapy?

answers.option: When his human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) viral load is approaching 1 million
Once he has stopped using drugs
When his CD4+ cell count is below 300
When he starts to show initial signs of infection

question: Which of these methods is not useful in the management of Clostridium difficile infections?
A 7-year-old girl presents to the office with a complaint of fever for the last 10 days. She also developed a red, spotty rash over her abdomen 2 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the best test for the diagnosis of enteric fever?
What does 'Risos sardonicus' refer to?

A 19-year-old man presents with right hypochondrial pain and fever for the last 5 days. He also mentions having a few episodes of bloody diarrhea one month ago. What is the most conclusive step in establishing the diagnosis?
What is the best confirmatory test for hydatid cyst disease?

A 31-year-old female presents with a painless skin rash behind her right ear. On examination, it is a patch-like hypopigmented area with reduced sensation and well-demarcated borders. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

question: A 40-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency after collapsing in his home. After regaining consciousness, he complains of right hypochondrial pain and on imaging, calcified cysts are observed in his liver. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements regarding primary HIV is incorrect?

answers.option: Fever with rash is one of the clinical features
High viral RNA loads are detected

question: Which one of these is a diagnostic feature of Echinococcal infection?
Which one of these is not a feature of tetanus?
What is the antibiotic of choice for established tetanus?
What is the earliest sign of tetanus?
What is the most common pulmonary disorder in an AIDS patient?
Which of these is not an indication for antiviral therapy for chickenpox infections?

answers.option: Chickenpox in immunocompromised patients regardless of duration
Chickenpox in pregnant women regardless of duration

question: A man with a known case of HIV presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, weight loss, and fatigue. He is diagnosed with the case of mycobacterium avium complex. What is the treatment used for this patient?

A patient in the hospital was on the ventilator and got treated for an illness with clindamycin, ethambutol, and some other antibiotics. He then got extubated and was started on meropenem 10 days ago. Two days ago he presented with watery diarrhea suggesting a C. difficile infection. How will this condition be managed?

answers.option: Stop all antibiotics and send stool sample for ova and parasite
Stop meropenem and give oral metronidazole

question: ELISA done for an HIV patient is stored for how many days?

answers.option: 10 ml blood at temperature 4°C for 2 day upto 6 days
10 ml blood at temperature 4°C for 3 day upto 7 days
10 ml blood at temperature 4°C for 5 day upto 9 days
10 ml blood at temperature 4°C for 4 day upto 8 days
10 ml blood at temperature 4°C for 1 day upto 5 days

question: What is the gold standard test for salmonella typhi?
Which of the following test is used to measure the efficacy of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART)?
What should be the target central venous pressure (CVP) in sepsis?
The CBC report of dengue hemorrhagic fever will show which of the following?

A 16-year-old male presents with a complaint of high-grade fever with chills and rigors for five days along with severe body aches and pains. On peripheral examination, the patient is febrile. On systemic examination, no significant finding was found except his petechial rashes all over the extremities. What would the most likely diagnosis be?
A patient presents with complaints of fever and body ache for the past two days. What is the best initial test for the diagnosis of dengue fever?

answers.option: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and c-reactive protein (CRP) tests

question: Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae, characterized by loss of sensation in the periphery. Which of the following is true regarding the duration of treatment of tuberculoid leprosy?

answers.option: Treatment is given for three months
Treatment is given for one year
Treatment is given for one month
Treatment is given for six months
Treatment is given for two years

question: A 26-year-old, pregnant woman is diagnosed with gonorrhea. There is a previous history of anaphylactic shock on the administration of amoxicillin. Which of the following drugs is given as a single dose?
Which of the following is gold standard for the diagnosis of malaria?

answers.option: Administration of chloroquine for sensitivity analysis
Immunochromatographic rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for malarial antigens
Blood film for microscopic examination of the parasite
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to detect plasmodium DNA
Rapid screening card agglutination test for antibody detection

question: Which of the following is used routinely in clinics for the diagnosis of malaria?

answers.option: Rapid screening card agglutination test for antibody detection
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to detect plasmodium DNA
Immunochromatographic rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for malarial antigens
Blood film for microscopic examination of the parasite
Administration of chloroquine for sensitivity analysis

question: A 29-year-old man presents with complaints of fever, which was initially low-grade and then became high-grade, headache, and abdominal discomfort. His vitals showed blood pressure 180/100 mmHg, and a pulse of 65 beats/min. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
How many stool samples are required for the typhoid test?
Which of the following is another name for visceral leishmaniasis?
Which test is helpful in the diagnosis of giardiasis?
Human cysticercosis is acquired by the ingestion of which of the following?
Ova of Schistosoma haematobium can be detected in which of the following?

A 45-year-old patient presents with right-sided focal fits. History reveals that he is an AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) patient. Magnetic resonance imaging shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the cortical grey-white matter of the brain. What is the cause of fits?
A 50-year-old male HIV patient is being evaluated for AIDS-defining diseases. Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining illness?

A 50-year-old female sustained injury from rusty metal on her right finger while cleaning. She is cautious and seeks emergency treatment. You washed her wound with normal saline and dressed it. Which infection is she at risk of acquiring?

A 25-year-old male had a sexual contact with a commercial sex worker during his business trip to UAE. He developed a painless ulcer at the penile shaft after one week. What investigation will diagnose the genital ulcer?

answers.option: Tzank smear on tissue biopsy from the ulcer

question: A 45-year-old male is suffering from high-grade fever, severe body ache, and bleeding from the nose and mouth since the last 2 days. He consulted his general physician but the prescribed medicines did not give any relief. He works as a butcher and handles alive animals. His complete blood count shows hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL, white blood cells 1200/mm³, platelet count 37000/mm³. What is the best treatment option for him?

answers.option: IV antibiotics to prevent bacterial infection
IV domperidone or any other prokinetic agent

question: A 45-year-old female had fever and chills. Malarial parasite was positive on MP-ICT. She was treated with artemisinin based combination therapy. She went to donate blood after one session. The blood bank refused donation because she had gametocytes on peripheral smear. She is worried and wants a retreatment. What should be the next step of management?

answers.option: Repeat peripheral smear from well reputed laboratory
A different antimalarial drug should be used
Repeat course of artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT)
Needs long term prophylaxis to clear the gametocytes

question: A medical worker accidentally gets pricked by a needle used on an HIV-positive patient. What is the risk percentage of him getting an HIV infection?
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used to treat which of the following infections in HIV-positive patients?
In an AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) patient, purplish, non-blanching nodules appear in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following infections in sexually active women does not cause vaginal discharge?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with abdominal pain, relative bradycardia, and a fever that started as low-grade but has been persistently increasing for days. He also has salmon-colored spots on his trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient presents to the clinic with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and a runny nose with red eyes. He, later on, notices a maculopapular rash beginning to appear on his forehead. What is the patient most likely suffering from?
What is the term used for diarrhea (with or without blood in stool) that starts acutely and occurs for at least 14 days?
A child presents with high-grade fever, runny nose, and cough. White lesions are found on the oral mucosa. What is the pathognomonic sign for measles?

A 28-year-old man has a fever, headache, and a rash present on his trunk and extremities with itching. On examinations, vesicles and papules of varying sizes are seen on his trunk and extremities and some are in the healing stage. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with hypopigmented lesions on his limbs and back. He has been treated with antifungals but did not heal. He has also developed polyarthritis with edema. He has thick cutaneous nerves, radial, ulnar, and tibial nerves. The nerves are painful and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient had a hypopigmented skin lesion on one side, which progressed to multiple sites. Some of these lesions resolved on their own and then new lesions appeared. He also has anorexia, fever, and weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A female patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of purulent vaginal discharge. Gram staining of the discharge reveals gram-negative diplococci. What is the best treatment?

A 35-year-old diabetic patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever associated with rigors and chills, and increased frequency of urine. She also complains of pain during micturition. Other systemic findings are unremarkable. What is the most accurate test for diagnosis?

A man presents to the clinic with the complaint of a thick, yellow, mucoid, and purulent urethral discharge. He has had a new sexual partner for two weeks. Which infections would you consider in this patient?

A patient is brought to the clinic with the complaint of fever, cough, dyspnea, and cyanosis. He also has tachycardia and his blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On auscultation, crackles and decreased breath sounds can be heard in the right lower lobe. What is the diagnosis?
The coagulation cascade in systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is mediated by which of the following?

A 40-year-old male presents with dyspnea, cyanosis, and tachycardia. He is a chain smoker and there is a ventilation-perfusion mismatch on the V/Q scan. Which of the following lung complications can result as a result of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)?
Which of the following is a late complication of measles?
There is a patient with a clear indication of sepsis. He also has marked hypotension. What is the most appropriate management at this point?

answers.option: Give him a heavy dose of corticosteroids as soon as possible
Aggressive fluid resuscitation to keep central venous pressure 8-12 mm Hg
Persistent blood transfusions to keep his Hb at >10 g/dl
Treat the patient with empirical antibiotics after culture and sensitivity

question: A man presents to the hospital with an altered level of consciousness two hours after falling in the washroom. He has pinpoint pupils with a pulse of 78 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg, and a fever of 107°F despite antipyretics. Sponging is also of no use. What is the most likely cause of fever?

A 35-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a prolonged history of fever and weight loss. On clinical examination, there is lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Complete blood count (CBC) shows pancytopenia. He is suspected of visceral leishmaniasis. Which of the following investigations is used for definitive diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis?

answers.option: Identification of amastigote in macrophages in tissue sample

question: A 16-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a three-day history of high-grade fever, flu, itchy red eyes, and rashes all over the body. On examination, the physician found Kolpik spots in the oral cavity and a maculopapular rash scattered all over the body. The most likely diagnosis will be?

A 50-year-old female while cleaning her home sustained a rusty metal injury on her right finger. She is very cautious and came to seek treatment at the emergency department. You have washed her wound with normal saline and dressed it. Which of the following infections she is at risk of acquiring?

A 20-year-old college student presented to the medical specialist with complaints of fever, extra-orbital pain, and fatigue for one week. On examination, the patient is febrile and has a macular skin rash. The lab results reveal a Hb of 11 g/dl, a TLC of 3500 cells/dl, a platelet count of 50,000, and an increased hematocrit. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presented to the skin specialist with complaints of skin lesions on his face and arms for six months. The lesions are hypopigmented and lack sensation. On examination, the skin over the brows and ears has thickened, and there are nodules on the face. He was diagnosed as having leprosy. Which of the following statements is correct?

answers.option: Its clinical presentation is not classical
There is no role for cell-mediated immunity, but granulomas are usually absent
The lepromin skin test is positive in the tuberculoid type of leprosy
Tuberculin skin test is positive for any type of leprosy
Lepromin skin testing is positive in lepromatous types of leprosy

question: A 19-year-old woman presented to the emergency department after complaining of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 2 hours. Her abdominal pain is sudden, and she has no history of fever or diarrhea. She had taken fried rice, grilled chicken, and vegetables for lunch five hours before at a local restaurant. What is the most likely mechanism responsible for the symptoms?

answers.option: Bacterial invasion of the small intestine
Proliferation with subsequent production of toxins by bacteria
Bacterial invasion of the large intestine

question: A 36-year-old man presented to the emergency room with complaints of fever and mild abdominal pain for 3 days. On examination, he is febrile (103°F) with jaundice and a palpable spleen. Plasmodium falciparum trophozoites are visible in the peripheral film. In cases of uncomplicated falciparum malaria, which treatment is recommended?

A 24-year-old man from Baluchistan presented to the dermatology clinic complaining of an erythematous nodule in his right arm that had been bothering him for a month. There are no such lesions located on the ears, lips, or oral mucosa. The systemic review was unremarkable. The histopathology of the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation in the dermis and peripherally located amastigotes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old male presented with fever and abdominal pain. His illness started with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. He has been unwell for the past 7 days and has per rectal bleeding for the last 2 days. Initially, he took per ciprofloxacin for 3 days followed by oral cefixime and azithromycin for 4 days. He was started on intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

answers.option: Complete blood picture with peripheral film

question: Which of the following is the best treatment for hydatid cyst?

A 20-year-old agricultural laborer from Brazil came with a history of progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort associated with loss of appetite for six months. On examination there was hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow smears revealed an abundance of amastigotes both intracellularly within the macrophages as well as extracellularly. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a fever lasting for three days, accompanied by mild abdominal pain. Upon examination, he exhibited a fever of 103°F and jaundice, along with a palpable spleen. A peripheral blood film revealed the presence of trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum. What is the preferred treatment for uncomplicated falciparum malaria?

A 30-year-old previously healthy male presents to the emergency department with a fever. He reports feeling generally unwell for the past three days, with associated chills and sweating. On examination, his temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), heart rate 100 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. He appears tired but is alert and oriented. His physical examination is unremarkable, with no focal signs of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?

answers.option: Start antipyretic medication and reassess after 24 hours
Order a complete blood count (CBC) with differential

question: An 18-year-old girl college student came to OPD with a complaint of fever. She looks well on the examination. She has an absence of sweating during defervescence and has a bizarre temperature chart with the absence of diurnal variation or temperature-related change in pulse rate. She has normal ESR and CRP. A few scars of self-harm were noticed on the left wrist. What is the most likely type of fever in her case?

A 30-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, currently on long-term steroid therapy, presents to the emergency room with a high-grade fever (maximum temperature of 103°F) that has persisted for four days. She subsequently developed a maculopapular rash that began on her face and chest and has now generalized. Additionally, she has been experiencing difficulty breathing and a dry cough for the past day. Upon examination, she is afebrile and has a red-purple rash, while bilateral coarse crackles were audible during auscultation. What is the likely diagnosis?
An 18-year-old boy with a fever and a vesicular rash for 2 days is admitted to the ward. With suspicion of chicken pox what necessary precautions should be taken to avoid exposing other patients?

answers.option: Single room isolation and droplet precautions
Single room isolation, airborne and contact precautions

question: A 50-year-old male presented in OPD with hypopigmented lesions on his hands and forearms, especially the elbows. He also complains of loss of sensation in these lesions. On examination, there is a loss of pinprick sensation in the affected areas and his ulnar nerve is palpable under the elbow. How would you confirm your diagnosis?
A young patient presents with high-grade fever for 4 days and a generalized blanchable rash. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test for dengue at this stage?

A 22-year-old male presented to OPD with a complaint of burning micturition and urethral discharge for 5 days. He admits to having sexual exposure with a sexual worker 2 weeks back. The most common causative organism of urethral discharge is:

A young male comes to the physician with complaints of high-grade fever and swelling in front of both ears causing difficulty in mouth opening. On examination, bilateral painful parotid enlargement was there. What will be the possible diagnosis?
